image.altText: A composite image of Anthony Albanese, two friends in a yes and no t-shirt and Lydia Thorpe.

items.synopsis: Australians across the country are heading to the polls to vote in the Voice to Parliament referendum. Follow our live blog for the latest updates.

title.children: Australians head to the polls to cast their vote in Voice to Parliament referendum

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here’s a sneak peek at the set for the ABC’s live referendum television coverage, kicking off in about five minutes from 5.30pm AEST. Preparations are well underway, with Indigenous affairs editor Bridget Brennan, Voice referendum correspondent Dan Bourchier, Insiders host David Speers, and chief political correspondent Laura Tingle in the studio ready to break down the results as they come in. And of course, we’ll have election analyst Antony Green on the touchscreen.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: It’s almost time for our television coverage

props.alt: Four people sit behind a desk on a tv set.

children.content: The ABC's referendum night panel.
Here’s a sneak peek at the set for the ABC’s live referendum television coverage, kicking off in about
five minutes
from
AEST
Preparations are well underway, with Indigenous affairs editor
Bridget Brennan
, Voice referendum correspondent
Dan Bourchier
, Insiders host
David Speers
, and chief political correspondent
Laura Tingle
in the studio ready to break down the results as they come in.
And of course, we’ll have election analyst
Antony Green
on the touchscreen.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Voting ends at 6pm wherever you are. That comes first on Norfolk Island, where voters are counted in the ACT federal electorate of Bean. An hour later, polls close in NSW, Vic, Tas and the ACT. Then comes SA, then Qld, then the NT, and finally WA. If it's not close, it's likely we'll know whether the referendum has passed or failed before WA voters put their pencils down. Here's your form guide on what to expect as the count begins tonight.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Votes will be counted in eastern states while other states are still voting

children.content: Voting ends at 6pm wherever you are.
That comes first on Norfolk Island, where voters are counted in the ACT federal electorate of Bean.
An hour later, polls close in NSW, Vic, Tas and the ACT. Then comes SA, then Qld, then the NT, and finally WA.
If it's not close, it's likely we'll know whether the referendum has passed or failed before WA voters put their pencils down.
Here's your form guide
on what to expect as the count begins tonight.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello, if you're just tuning in, the first polls in Australia have closed in Norfolk Island. It's just after 6pm over there and their vote count starts now.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Polls in Norfolk Island are now closed

children.content: Hello, if you're just tuning in, the first polls in Australia have closed in
Norfolk Island
It's just after 6pm over there and their vote count starts now.

image.altText: Barnaby Joyce, Michaelia Cash and Bridget McKenzie sitting in front of protesters at the national press club

items.synopsis: As Australians hit the polls to have their say in the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum, here's a look back — in pictures — at how we got here.

title.children: In pictures: The Indigenous Voice to Parliament debate of 2023

image.altText: Family in a car with mattresses and children on the roof drive street in Gaza

items.synopsis: Residents of Gaza City will be given an additional six hours to evacuate, the Israeli Army Arabic language spokesman Avichay Adraee has said. Follow live.

title.children: Civilians given additional six hours to evacuate Gaza, Israeli army spokesman says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israeli Army arabic language spokesman Avichay Adraee has posted on X, formerly Twitter, that residents of Gaza City will be allowed to leave on two roads between 10am and 4pm local time. It's currently just before 9am in Gaza. The post on X, which includes a map, translated from Arabic into English reads: An important statement to the residents of Gaza City  In recent days, we have appealed to you to leave Gaza City to the south of Wadi Gaza in order to preserve your safety. I would like to inform you that the IDF will allow movement on the indicated streets without any harm between the hours of 10:00-16:00. For your safety, take advantage of the short time to move south — from Beit Hanoun to Khan Yunis. If you care about yourself and your loved ones, go south as instructed. Rest assured that Hamas leaders have taken care of themselves and are taking cover from strikes in the region. Residents of the beach, sand, and west of Olive will also be allowed to move on Daldul and Al-Sana Streets towards Salah Al-Din and Al-Bahr Streets.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli Army will allow safe movement out of Gaza City for six hours

children.content: The Israeli Army arabic language spokesman Avichay Adraee has posted on X, formerly Twitter, that residents of Gaza City will be allowed to leave on two roads between 10am and 4pm local time.
It's currently just before 9am in Gaza.
The post on X, which includes a map, translated from Arabic into English reads:

An important statement to the residents of Gaza City  In recent days, we have appealed to you to leave Gaza City to the south of Wadi Gaza in order to preserve your safety. I would like to inform you that the IDF will allow movement on the indicated streets without any harm between the hours of 10:00-16:00. For your safety, take advantage of the short time to move south — from Beit Hanoun to Khan Yunis. If you care about yourself and your loved ones, go south as instructed. Rest assured that Hamas leaders have taken care of themselves and are taking cover from strikes in the region. Residents of the beach, sand, and west of Olive will also be allowed to move on Daldul and Al-Sana Streets towards Salah Al-Din and Al-Bahr Streets.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel Defense Force spokesperson Jonathan Conricus said in the live stream there were Israeli Reserve soldiers around the Gaza Strip awaiting information for the next stage of the operation. Mr Conricus has reaffirmed the IDF's objective was to target Hamas. "The end state of this war is that we will dismantle Hamas and their military capabilities and fundamentally change the situation so that Hamas never again has the ability to inflict any damage on Israeli civilians or soldiers," he said. He said in the broadcast that "Palestinian civilians in Gaza are not our enemies." "If they were, the situation in Gaza would be entirely different," he said. "We are trying to do the right thing, we are trying to evacuate civilians in order to minimise the risk for them."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The IDF releases situational update

children.content: Israel Defense Force spokesperson Jonathan Conricus said in the live stream there were Israeli Reserve soldiers around the Gaza Strip awaiting information for the next stage of the operation.
Mr Conricus has reaffirmed the IDF's objective was to target Hamas.

"The end state of this war is that we will dismantle Hamas and their military capabilities and fundamentally change the situation so that Hamas never again has the ability to inflict any damage on Israeli civilians or soldiers," he said.
He said in the broadcast that "Palestinian civilians in Gaza are not our enemies."
"If they were, the situation in Gaza would be entirely different," he said.
"We are trying to do the right thing, we are trying to evacuate civilians in order to minimise the risk for them."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's military says it has struck a Hezbollah target in southern Lebanon in response to the "infiltration of unidentified aerial objects into Israel" as well as an Israeli drone coming under fire in the area. The IDF earlier reported its aerial defences had intercepted two unidentified objects above the port city of Haifa, about 140 kilometres south of the border with Lebanon, as well as a single object above the nearby Arab-majority city of Shfaram.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: IDF strikes Hezbollah after 'unidentified objects' enter airspace

children.content: Israel's military says it has struck a Hezbollah target in southern Lebanon in response to the "infiltration of unidentified aerial objects into Israel" as well as an Israeli drone coming under fire in the area.

The IDF earlier reported its aerial defences had intercepted two unidentified objects above the port city of Haifa, about 140 kilometres south of the border with Lebanon, as well as a single object above the nearby Arab-majority city of Shfaram.

image.altText: Three posters with photographs of people and the words 'bring them home'

items.synopsis: A week after Hamas terrorists' brutal attack on Israel, up to 150 kidnap victims remain in Gaza. Experts on hostage negotiation and terrorism say the world now faces several difficult choices.

title.children: The world's never seen a hostage crisis quite like this. Here's how it could play out

image.altText: A woman, a man and two young children look at the camera, surrounded by luggage and other people

items.synopsis: Tal Raymond, Dana Elhadad and their two young children were among the first Australians at Tel Aviv's Ben Gurion Airport for a Qantas repatriation flight on Friday, but not all of them got on board.

title.children: 'Hardest decision I've ever had to make': Aussie families torn apart at Tel Aviv airport

image.altText: A person in a crowd holds up a sign with the Aboriginal flag and the words "Voice to Parliament".

items.synopsis: A No vote — and how we got to one — will change the way we see ourselves, and send the most unloving of messages to Indigenous Australians, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The public sentiment shift that turned the tide of the Voice referendum

image.altText: Signs for Yes and No seen at a voting centre in Brisbane.

items.synopsis: The prime minister delivers his most fervent plea yet for the Yes campaign, as more than 9 million people head to the polls to vote in the Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: PM makes impassioned final Voice plea, Dutton repeats 'risky' claim as country votes

image.altText: Virgin, Qantas planes

title.children: Why 'cabotage' could be part of the plan for cheaper flights in Australia

image.altText: A woman holding a large handbag and wearing a scarf who looks wealthy walks the street.

items.synopsis: There was a time when the name of one whistleblower was on everyone's lips. Kathy Jackson was lauded as a "revolutionary" — but in the shadows was another person waiting to blow the whistle on her.

title.children: The man who blew the whistle on whistleblower Kathy Jackson and revealed her as a fraud

image.altText: Victoria Beckham and David Beckham pose for a photo, wearing suits, in front of a Netflix media wall

items.synopsis: The Posh and Becks story is a distortion of the Cinderella legend, as triumph isn't the result of noblesse oblige, of being selected, but the result of middle class striving that Britain has long struggled to understand, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: In their distorted Cinderella legend, the Beckhams get the last laugh

image.altText: A woman sobs as people stand against a sandstone wall at a funeral

items.synopsis: Israel is preparing to carry out a ground operation with a mission to "destroy Hamas". But what then? What is the political reality and make-up of Gaza and what would it look like without Hamas, asks John Lyons.

title.children: A reeling Israel is on the brink of razing Gaza – and the outlook is grim

image.altText: Palestinians drive down a road on motorbikes, cars, tractors and utility trucks

items.synopsis: Thousands of Palestinians flee to southern Gaza in search of refuge after Israel warns them to leave before an expected ground offensive against Hamas in retaliation for the deadliest attack in Israel's history.

title.children: Hamas accused of using Gaza residents as a 'shield' as Israeli ground invasion looms

image.altText: Long purple petals opening up from the yellow centre of a flower.

items.synopsis: Indigenous horticulturalists have taken 21 cuttings of the first known purple Banksia spinulosa. But it remains to be seen whether they will flower, and what colour the petals will be.

title.children: Discovery of 'one in a billion' native plant sparks hope for more purple flowers

image.altText: Costa, who has long hair and a bushy beard, smiles against a blue backdrop, with images of a cheese toastie and kimchi.

title.children: Eating burgers with a knife and fork and even killing houseplants: Costa reveals his darkest secrets

image.altText: A woman walks past "vote yes" and "vote no" signs on a fence.

items.synopsis: The nation is bound for the ballot box today to cast their vote in a referendum that could shape the country for generations to come — but the path to this poll has been a rocky one.

title.children: It once seemed unlikely to ever happen, but today Australians will vote on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament

items.synopsis: Unless the result is very close, we'll know tonight whether Australians have voted to change the Constitution to enshrine an Indigenous Voice to Parliament. Here's what to watch out for.

items.synopsis: Many Israeli and Palestinian people in Australia know someone who has either been killed, injured, kidnapped, displaced, or is in hiding. As the conflict escalates, they fear more bad news.

title.children: Naturists 'completely locked out' of South Australian nude beach

image.altText: Tim Tszyu looks to one side

items.synopsis: St Kilda have extended their AFLW winning streak to a club-record four games by defeating Greater Western Sydney by 13 points at Moorabbin.

title.children: Saints account for Giants to keep AFLW finals hopes alive

image.altText: West Indies batter Stafanie Taylor walks off the field as Australia fielders celebrate.

items.synopsis: After rain stopped them taking a commanding 2-0 lead over West Indies in their ODI series, Australia is trying to wrap up the three-game series with another big win. Check out the live scores and stats in our ScoreCentre.

title.children: Australia coasts to easy win in final ODI against West Indies

image.altText: A Cruise driverless taxi in San Francisco

items.synopsis: A recent Californian trial saw self-driving taxis crash into a fire truck and get bogged in wet cement. Such incidents erode trust in the technology, writes autonomous systems researcher Zena Assaad.

title.children: San Francisco's driverless taxis marked a new era in transportation. Then the problems started

image.altText: Haiti's President Jovenel Moïse leaves a museum

items.synopsis: In 2021, a doctor and pastor met with his friends in Florida allegedly to arrange the overthrow of the Haitian president. Now Kenya is being sent in to help a country plunged into chaos.

title.children: How a group of Florida men allegedly plotted the assassination of the Haitian president and sent the country into chaos

image.altText: A range of old cars in a car museum.

items.synopsis: Experts believe the future of vehicles will include a mix of technologies as the planet becomes more environmentally conscious.

title.children: As the world becomes more environmentally conscious, what does this mean for classic and prestige car lovers?

image.altText: A young girl riding her bike on a dirt track.

items.synopsis: A velodrome once home to Australian cycling champion Anna Meares is set to play a crucial role in the lead-up to the Brisbane 2032 Olympic Games.

title.children: How Olympian Anna Meares helped turn home town's crumbling concrete track into international attraction

image.altText: A young woman gazes at a magenta flower

items.synopsis: When Lauren Bouyer tries to conjure an image in her mind's eye, nothing happens. Researchers say her condition, aphantasia, is more prevalent than previously thought.

title.children: Loren can't 'see' things in her imagination. It's more common than you might think
